definitions.definition: to close or join together the two parts of something; to become closed or joined together
definitions.sensetop: fasten somethingfasten something upfasten (something) with somethingfasten + adv./prep.

examples.text: Emma shivered and fastened the top button of her coat.
He fastened up his coat and hurried out.
The garment is fastened with a sash.
The dress fastens at the back.
a short yellow skirt which fastens up the side.
The gown fastens down the front with Velcro.

definitions.definition: to close something so that it will not open; to be closed in this way

examples.text: Fasten the gates securely so that they do not blow open.
Make sure all the exits are **securely fastened**.

definitions.definition: to fix something in a particular position

examples.text: Use the special kit provided to fasten the child seat in the car.
A gold locket was fastened around Eleanor's neck.
Each bundle of 100 votes was rolled up and fastened with a rubber band.

definitions.definition: to attach or tie one thing to another thing
definitions.sensetop: fasten A and B togetherfasten A to B

examples.text: He fastened the papers together with a paper clip.
She fastened the rope to a tree.

definitions.definition: if you fasten your arms around somebody, your teeth into something, etc., or if your arms, teeth, etc. fasten around, into, etc. somebody/something, you hold the person/thing strongly with your arms, etc.

examples.text: The dog fastened its teeth in his leg.
His hand fastened on her arm.

definitions.definition: if you fasten your eyes on somebody/something or your eyes fasten on somebody/something, you look at them for a long time

examples.text: He fastened his gaze on her face.

wordOrigin: Old English fæstnian ‘make sure’, also ‘immobilize’, of West Germanic origin; related to fast ‘quick’.
